name: Ordinary Bitter
clarity: Chill haze is allowable at cold temperatures
perceived_malt: Low to medium residual malt sweetness should be present
fermentation: Mild carbonation traditionally characterizes draft-cask versions, but in bottled versions, a slight increase in carbon dioxide content is acceptable. Fruity-estery and very low diacetyl flavors are acceptable, but should be minimized in this form of Bitter.

name: Special Bitter or Best Bitter
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Medium residual malt sweetness should be present
perceived_hop: Very low to medium at the brewer's discretion
fermentation: Low carbonation traditionally characterizes draft-cask versions, but in bottled versions, a slight increase in carbon dioxide content is acceptable. Fruity-estery aromas and flavors and very low levels of diacetyl are acceptable, but should be minimized in this form of Bitter. The absence of diacetyl is also acceptable.

name: Extra Special Bitter
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Medium to medium-high
fermentation: Low carbonation traditionally characterizes draft-cask versions, but in bottled versions, a slight increase in carbon dioxide content is acceptable. The overall impression is refreshing and thirst quenching. Fruity-estery and very low diacetyl characters are acceptable, but should be minimized in this form of Bitter. The absence of diacetyl is also acceptable.

name: Scottish-Style Light Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Malty, caramel aroma may be present. A low to medium-low, soft and chewy caramel malt flavor should be present.
fermentation: Yeast attributes such as diacetyl and sulfur are acceptable at very low levels. Bottled versions may contain higher amounts of carbon dioxide than is typical for mildly carbonated draft versions. Fruity-estery aromas, if evident, are low.

name: Scottish-Style Heavy Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Malty, caramel aroma is present. The style exhibits a medium degree of sweet malt and caramel. The overall impression is smooth and balanced.
fermentation: Yeast attributes such as diacetyl and sulfur are acceptable at very low levels. Bottled versions may contain higher amounts of carbon dioxide than is typical for mildly carbonated draft versions. Fruity-estery aromas, if evident, are low.
body: Medium with a soft chewy character

name: Scottish-Style Export Ale
color: Medium amber to dark chestnut brown
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Sweet malt and caramel aromas and flavors define the character of a Scottish Export
fermentation: Fruity-estery character may be apparent. Yeast attributes such as diacetyl and sulfur are acceptable at very low levels. Bottled versions may contain higher amounts of carbon dioxide than is typical for mildly carbonated draft versions.

name: English-Style Summer Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Residual malt sweetness is low to medium. Torrified or malted wheat is often used in quantities of 25 percent or less. Malt attributes such as biscuity or low levels of caramel are present.
perceived_hop: English, American or noble-type hop aroma should be low to medium. English, American or noble-type hop flavor should not be assertive and should be well balanced with malt character.
fermentation: Mild carbonation traditionally characterizes draft-cask versions, but in bottled versions, a slight increase in carbon dioxide content is acceptable. Low to moderate fruity-estery character is acceptable. No diacetyl or DMS character should be apparent.
notes: The overall impression is refreshing and thirst quenching

name: Classic English-Style Pale Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Low to medium malt aroma and flavor is present. Low caramel character is allowable.
perceived_hop: Earthy and herbal English-variety hop character should be perceived, but may result from the skillful use of hops of other origin.
fermentation: Fruity-estery character is moderate to strong. Diacetyl can be absent or may be perceived at very low levels.

name: English-Style India Pale Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Medium malt flavor should be present
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is medium to high, and often flowery. Hops from a variety of origins may be used to contribute to a high hopping rate. Earthy and herbal English-variety hop character should be perceived, but may result from the skillful use of hops of other origin.
fermentation: Fruity-estery flavors are moderate to very high. Traditional interpretations are characterized by medium to medium-high alcohol content. The use of water with high mineral content results in a crisp, dry beer with a subtle and balanced character of sulfur compounds. Diacetyl can be absent or may be perceived at very low levels.
notes: Non-English hops may be used for bitterness or for approximating traditional English hop character. The use of water with high mineral content may result in a crisp, dry beer rather than a malt-accentuated version.

name: Strong Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Medium to high malt and caramel sweetness. Very low levels of roast malt may be perceived.
perceived_bitterness: Evident but minimal, and balanced with malt flavors.
fermentation: A rich, often sweet and complex fruity-estery character can contribute to the profile of Strong Ales. Alcohol types can be varied and complex. Very low levels of diacetyl are acceptable.

name: Old Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Fruity-estery aroma can contribute to the malt aroma and flavor profile. Old Ales have a malt and sometimes caramel sweetness.
fermentation: Fruity-estery flavors can contribute to the character of this ale. Alcohol types can be varied and complex. A distinctive quality of Old Ales is that they undergo an aging process, often for years. Aging can occur on their yeast either in bulk storage or through conditioning in the bottle. This contributes to a rich, wine-like and often sweet oxidized character. Complex estery attributes may also emerge. Very low diacetyl character may be evident and is acceptable.
notes: Wood-aged attributes such as vanilla are acceptable. Horsey, goaty, leathery and phenolic character and acidity produced by

name: English-Style Pale Mild Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Malt flavor and aroma dominate the flavor profile
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor range from very low to low
fermentation: Very low diacetyl flavors may be appropriate in this low-alcohol beer. Fruity-estery character is very low to medium-low.

name: English-Style Dark Mild Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Malt and caramel should be evident in the aroma and flavor while licorice and roast malt may also be present
fermentation: Very low diacetyl flavors may be appropriate in this low-alcohol beer. Fruity-estery character is very low to medium-low.

name: English-Style Brown Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Roast malt may contribute to a biscuit or toasted aroma profile. Roast malt may contribute to the flavor profile. Malt profile can range from dry to sweet.
fermentation: Low to medium-low levels of fruity-estery flavors are appropriate. Diacetyl, if evident, should be very low.

name: Brown Porter
color: Dark brown to very dark. May have red tint.
clarity: Beer color may be too dark to perceive clarity. When clarity is perceivable, chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures.
perceived_malt: Low to medium malt sweetness. Caramel and chocolate character is acceptable. Strong roast barley or strong burnt or black malt character should not be perceived.
fermentation: Fruity-estery flavors are acceptable. Diacetyl should not be perceived.

name: Robust Porter
clarity: Opaque
perceived_malt: Medium to medium-high. Malty sweetness, roast malt, cocoa and caramel should be in harmony with bitterness from dark malts.
fermentation: Fruity esters should be evident and balanced with all other characters. Diacetyl should not be perceived.

name: Sweet Stout or Cream Stout
clarity: Opaque
perceived_malt: Medium to medium-high. Malt sweetness, chocolate and caramel should contribute to the aroma and should dominate the flavor profile. Roast flavor may be perceived. Low to medium-low roasted malt-derived bitterness should be present.
perceived_bitterness: Low to medium-low and serves to balance and suppress some of the sweetness without contributing apparent flavor and aroma
fermentation: Fruity-estery flavors, if present, are low. Diacetyl should not be perceived.
body: Full-bodied. Body can be increased with the addition of milk sugar (lactose).

name: Oatmeal Stout
clarity: Beer color may be too dark to perceive. When clarity is perceivable, chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures.
perceived_malt: Coffee, caramel, roasted malt or chocolate aromas should be prominent. Roasted malt character of caramel or chocolate should be smooth without bitterness.
perceived_hop: Optional, but should not upset the overall balance.
fermentation: Oatmeal is used in the grist, resulting in a pleasant, full flavor without being grainy. Fruity-estery aroma can range from not perceived to very low. Fruity-estery flavor is very low. Diacetyl should be absent or at extremely low levels.

name: Scotch Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Scotch Ales are aggressively malty with a rich and dominant sweet malt aroma and flavor. A caramel character is often part of the profile. Dark roasted malt flavors may be evident at low levels.
fermentation: Fruity esters, if present, are generally at low levels. Low levels of diacetyl are acceptable.
notes: A brewery-fresh experience is intended with these beers. Oxidation is not an acceptable character. Pleasantly oxidized Scotch Ales should be classified in Aged Beer categories.

name: British-Style Imperial Stout
color: Ranging from dark copper typical of some historic examples, to very dark more typical of contemporary examples
clarity: Opaque in darker versions. When clarity is perceivable, chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures.
perceived_malt: Extremely rich malty flavor, often expressed as toffee or caramel, and may be accompanied by very low roasted malt astringency.
perceived_hop: Very low to medium, with floral, citrus or herbal qualities.
perceived_bitterness: Medium, and should not overwhelm the overall balance. The bitterness may be higher in darker versions while maintaining balance with sweet malt.
fermentation: High alcohol content is evident. High fruity-estery character may be present. Diacetyl should be absent.
notes: This style was also originally called 'Russian Imperial Stout.'

name: British-Style Barley Wine Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Residual malty sweetness is high
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor are very low to medium. English type hops are often used but are not required for this style.
fermentation: Complexity of alcohols and fruity-estery attributes are often high and balanced with the high alcohol content. Low levels of diacetyl are acceptable. Caramel and some oxidized character (vinous aromas and/or flavors) may be considered positive attributes.

name: Irish-Style Red Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Slight yeast haze is acceptable for bottle conditioned examples.
perceived_malt: Low to medium candy-like caramel malt sweetness should be present in flavor. A toasted malt character should be present and there may be a slight roast barley or roast malt presence.
fermentation: Low levels of fruity-estery aroma and flavor are acceptable. Diacetyl levels may range from absent to very low.

name: Classic Irish-Style Dry Stout
clarity: Opaque
perceived_malt: The prominence of coffee-like roasted barley and a moderate degree of roasted malt aroma and flavor defines much of the character. Dry stouts achieve a dry-roasted character through the use of roasted barley. Initial malt and light caramel flavors give way to a distinctive dry-roasted bitterness in the finish.
perceived_hop: European hop character may range from not perceived to low in aroma and flavor
fermentation: Fruity-estery character is low relative to malt and roasted barley as well as hop bitterness. Diacetyl, if present, should be very low. Slight acidity may be perceived but is not required.
notes: Head retention should be persistent

name: Export-Style Stout
clarity: Opaque
perceived_malt: Coffee-like roasted barley and roasted malt aromas are prominent. Initial malt and light caramel flavors give way to a distinctive dry-roasted bitterness in the finish.
perceived_bitterness: May be analytically high, but the perception is lessened by malt sweetness.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aroma and flavor is low. Diacetyl should be negligible or not perceived. Slight acidity is acceptable.
notes: Head retention should be persistent

name: Golden or Blonde Ale
clarity: Chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Light malt sweetness should be present in flavor
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor should be low to medium-low, present but not dominant.
fermentation: Fruity esters may be perceived at low levels. Diacetyl and DMS should not be perceived.
body: Low to medium with a crisp finish

name: American-Style Amber/Red Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Medium-high to high maltiness with low to medium caramel character
perceived_hop: American-variety hop character may range from low to medium-low in aroma and flavor
fermentation: Fruity-estery aroma and flavor are low, if present. Diacetyl can be absent or perceived at very low levels.

name: American-Style Pale Ale
color: Deep golden to copper or light brown
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Hop haze is allowable at any temperature.
perceived_malt: Low caramel malt aroma is allowable. Low to medium maltiness may include low caramel malt character.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is high, exhibiting floral, fruity (berry, tropical, stone fruit and other), sulfur/diesel-like, onion-garlic-catty, citrusy, piney or resinous character that was originally associated with American-variety hops. Hops with these attributes now also originate from countries other than the USA.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aroma and flavor may be low to high. Diacetyl should not be perceived.

name: Juicy or Hazy Pale Ale
clarity: Low to very high degree of cloudiness is typical of these beers. Starch, yeast, hop, protein and/or other compounds contribute to a wide range of hazy appearance within this category.
perceived_malt: Low to low-medium malt aroma and flavor may be present
perceived_hop: Medium-high to very high hop aroma and flavor are present, with attributes typical of hops from any origin.
perceived_bitterness: Low to medium. Perceived impression of bitterness is soft and well-integrated into overall balance, and may differ significantly from measured or calculated IBU levels.
fermentation: Low to medium fruity-estery aroma and flavor may be present, but are usually overwhelmed by hop fruitiness. Diacetyl should not be perceived.
body: Medium-low to medium-high. Perceived silky or full mouthfeel may contribute to overall flavor profile.
notes: Grist may include a small amount of oat, wheat or other adjuncts to promote haziness. Descriptors such as 'juicy' are often used to describe the taste and aroma hop-derived attributes present in these beers.

name: American-Style Strong Pale Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Hop haze is allowable at any temperature.
perceived_malt: Low caramel malt aroma is allowable. Low level maltiness may include low caramel malt character.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is high, exhibiting floral, fruity (berry, tropical, stone fruit and other), sulfur/diesel-like, onion-garlic-catty, citrusy, piney or resinous character that was originally associated with American-variety hops. Hops with these attributes now also originate from countries other than the USA.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aroma and flavor may be low to high. Diacetyl should not be perceived.

name: Session India Pale Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Hop haze is allowable at any temperature.
perceived_malt: A low to medium maltiness should be present in aroma and flavor.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor are medium to high and can display qualities from a wide variety of hops from all over the world. Overall hop character is assertive.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aroma and flavor is low to medium. Diacetyl should not be perceived.
notes: Beers exceeding 5.0% abv are not considered Session India Pale Ales. Beers under 5.0% abv (4.0% abw) which meet the criteria for another classic or traditional style category are not considered Session India Pale Ales.

name: American-Style India Pale Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Hop haze is allowable at any temperature.
perceived_malt: Low-medium to medium maltiness is present in aroma and flavor
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is high, exhibiting floral, fruity (berry, tropical, stone fruit and other), sulfur/diesel-like, onion-garlic-catty, citrusy, piney or resinous character that was originally associated with American-variety hops. Hops with these attributes now also originate from countries other than the USA.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aroma and flavor may be low to high. Diacetyl should not be perceived.
notes: The use of water with high mineral content may result in a crisp, dry beer rather than a malt-accentuated version. Sugar adjuncts may be used to enhance body and balance. Hops of varied origins may be used for bitterness or for approximating traditional American character.

name: Juicy or Hazy India Pale Ale
clarity: Low to very high degree of cloudiness is typical of these beers. Starch, yeast, hop, protein and/or other compounds contribute to a wide range of hazy appearance within this category.
perceived_malt: Low to low-medium malt aroma and flavor may be present
perceived_hop: Medium-high to very high hop aroma and flavor are present, with attributes typical of hops from any origin
fermentation: Low to medium fruity-estery aroma and flavor may be present, but are usually overwhelmed by hop fruitiness. Diacetyl should not be perceived.
body: Medium-low to medium-high. Perceived silky or full mouthfeel may contribute to overall flavor profile.
notes: Grist may include a small amount of oat, wheat or other adjuncts to promote haziness. Descriptors such as 'juicy' are often used to describe the taste and aroma hop-derived attributes present in these beers.

name: Pale American-Belgo-Style Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Low
perceived_hop: Medium to very high, exhibiting American-type hop aromas not usually found in traditional Belgian styles.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aroma is low to moderate. Fruity-estery flavor should be medium to high. Belgian yeast attributes such as banana, berry, apple, coriander, spice and/or smoky-phenolic should be in balance with malt and hops. Diacetyl, sulfur and
notes: Pale American-Belgo-Style Ales are either 1) non-Belgian beer types portraying the unique characters imparted by yeasts typically used in big, fruity Belgian-style ales, or 2) defined Belgian-style beers displaying a unique character of American hops. These beers are unique unto themselves.

name: Dark American-Belgo-Style Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Perception of roasted malts or barley can be very low to robust
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is medium to very high, exhibiting American-type hop aromas not usually found in traditional Belgian styles.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aroma and flavors are medium to high. Attributes typical of fermentation with Belgian yeast such as banana, coriander, spice and/or smoky-phenolic should be in balance with malt and hops. Diacetyl, sulfur and
notes: Dark American-Belgo-Style Ales are either 1) non-Belgian darker beer types portraying the unique attributes imparted by yeasts typically used in big fruity Belgian-style ales, or 2) defined darker Belgian-style beers displaying a unique character of American hops. These beers are unique unto themselves.

name: American-Style Brown Ale
color: Deep copper to very dark brown
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Roasted malt, caramel and chocolate aromas and flavors should be medium.
fermentation: Low to med-low. Fruity-estery aromas and flavors may be present. Diacetyl should not be perceived.

name: American-Style Black Ale
clarity: Opaque
perceived_malt: Low to low-medium caramel malt and dark roasted malt aromas may be evident. Low to low-medium caramel malt and dark roasted malt flavors are evident. Astringency and burnt character of roast malt should be absent.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is medium-high to high, with fruity, citrusy, piney, floral, herbal or other aromas derived from hops of all origins.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aromas and flavors should be low to medium. Diacetyl should not be perceived.

name: American-Style Stout
clarity: Opaque
perceived_malt: Coffee-like roasted barley and roasted malt aromas are prominent. Low to medium malt sweetness with low to medium caramel, chocolate, and/or roasted coffee flavor should be present, with a distinct dry-roasted bitterness in the finish. Astringency from roasted malt and roasted barley is low. Slight roasted malt acidity is acceptable.
perceived_hop: Medium to high, often with citrusy and/or resiny hop qualities typical of many American hop varieties.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aroma and flavor is low. Diacetyl should be negligible or not perceived.
notes: Head retention should be persistent

name: American-Style Imperial Porter
clarity: Opaque
perceived_malt: No roast barley or strong burnt/black malt character should be perceived. Medium malt, caramel and cocoa sweetness should be present.
fermentation: Fruity-estery flavors and aromas should be evident but not overpowering and should complement hop character and malt-derived sweetness. Diacetyl should be absent.

name: American-Style Imperial Stout
clarity: Opaque
perceived_malt: Extremely rich malty aroma is typical. Extremely rich malty flavor with full sweet malt character is typical. Roasted malt astringency and bitterness can be moderate but should not dominate the overall character.
perceived_hop: Medium-high to high with floral, citrus and/or herbal character.
perceived_bitterness: Medium-high to very high and balanced with rich malt character.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aromas and flavors are high. Diacetyl should be absent.

name: Double Hoppy Red Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Medium to medium-high caramel malt character should be present in flavor and aroma. Low to medium biscuit or toasted malt character may also be present.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma is high, derived from any variety of hops. Hop flavor is high and balanced with other beer attributes.
fermentation: Alcohol content is medium to high. Complex alcohol flavors may be evident. Fruity-estery aromas and flavors are medium. Diacetyl should not be perceived.

name: Imperial Red Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Medium to high caramel malt character is present in aroma and flavor
perceived_hop: High hop aroma and flavor, derived from any variety of hops. Hop flavor is prominent, and balanced with other beer attributes.
fermentation: Very high alcohol is a hallmark of this style. Complex alcohol flavors may be evident. Fruity-estery aromas and flavors are medium. Diacetyl should not be perceived.

name: American-Style Imperial or Double India Pale Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Haze created by dry hopping is allowable at any temperature.
perceived_malt: Low to high
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is very high. Hop character should be fresh and evident, derived from any variety of hops. Hop flavor should not be harsh.
fermentation: Alcohol content is medium-high to high and evident. Fruity-estery aroma and flavor is medium to high. Diacetyl should not be perceived.
notes: This style of beer should exhibit the fresh character of hops. Oxidized or aged character should not be present.

name: Juicy or Hazy Imperial or Double India Pale Ale
clarity: Low to very high degree of cloudiness is typical of these beers. Starch, yeast, hop, protein and/or other compounds contribute to a wide range of hazy appearance within this category.
perceived_malt: Low to high malt aroma and flavor may be present
perceived_hop: High to very high hop aroma and flavor are present, with attributes typical of hops from any origin.
perceived_bitterness: Low to medium. Perceived impression of bitterness is soft and well-integrated into overall balance, and may differ significantly from measured or calculated IBU levels.
fermentation: Low to medium fruity-estery aroma and flavor may be present, but are usually overwhelmed by hop character. Diacetyl should not be perceived.
body: Medium to high. Perceived silky or full mouthfeel may contribute to overall flavor profile.
notes: Grist may include a small amount of oat, wheat or other adjuncts to promote haziness. Descriptors such as 'juicy' are often used to describe the taste and aroma hop-derived attributes present in these beers.

name: American-Style Barley Wine Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Caramel and/or toffee malt aromas are often present. High residual malty sweetness, often with caramel and/or toffee flavors, should be present.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is medium to very high. American hop varieties are often used, but are not required for this style.
fermentation: Complex alcohols are evident. Fruity-estery aromas and flavors are often high. Very low levels of diacetyl are acceptable.
notes: Vinous, sherry-like or port-like attributes arising from oxidation may be considered positive when in harmony with overall flavor profile.

name: American-Style Wheat Wine Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Bread, wheat, honey and/or caramel malt aromas and flavors are often present. High residual malt sweetness should be present.
fermentation: Fruity-estery flavors and aromas are often high and balanced by a complexity of alcohols and high alcohol content. Very low levels of diacetyl are acceptable. Phenolic yeast character, sulfur, and/or DMS should not be present. Oxidized, stale and aged attributes are not typical of this style.
notes: This style is brewed with at least 50% wheat malt.

name: Smoke Porter
clarity: Opaque
perceived_malt: Smoked porters will exhibit mild to assertive smoke malt aroma and flavor in balance with other aroma attributes. Black malt character can be perceived in some porters, while others may be absent of strong roast character. Roast barley character is absent to low depending on underlying porter style being smoked. Medium to high malt sweetness, and caramel and chocolate flavors, are acceptable.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aromas and flavors are acceptable

name: American-Style Sour Ale
color: Pale to black depending on underlying beer style.
clarity: Chill haze, bacteria and yeast-induced haze is acceptable at any temperature.
perceived_malt: Low. In darker versions, roasted malt, caramel and chocolate aromas and flavors should be present at low levels.
fermentation: Moderate to intense, yet balanced, fruity-estery aromas and flavors are evident. Diacetyl, DMS and
notes: Such beers exhibiting wood-derived characters or characters of liquids previously aged in wood are categorized as Wood-Aged Sour Beer.

name: German-Style Koelsch
clarity: Chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Malt character is very low to low with soft sweetness. Caramel character should not be evident.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is low, and if evident, should express noble hop character.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aromas and flavors should be absent or present at very low levels. Light pear-apple-Riesling wine-like fruitiness may be apparent, but is not required for this style. Diacetyl should not be perceived.
body: Low to medium-low. Dry and crisp.
notes: Traditional examples often display persistent head retention. Small amounts of wheat can be used in brewing beers of this style. Koelsch-style beers are fermented at warmer temperatures than is typical for lagers, but at lower temperatures than most English and Belgian-style ales. They are aged cold. Ale yeast is used for fermentation. Lager yeast is sometimes used for bottle conditioning or final cold conditioning.

name: German-Style Altbier
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: A variety of malts including wheat may be used to produce medium-low to medium malt aroma and flavor. Roast malt attributes may be present at very low levels.
perceived_hop: Low to medium. Character should reflect traditional German noble hops.
perceived_bitterness: Medium to very high, although 25 to 35 IBU is typical for Altbiers originating in Dusseldorf.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aroma should be absent or very low. Fruity-estery flavors can be low. No diacetyl should be perceived.
notes: The Altbier style is originally from the Dusseldorf area. The overall impression is clean, crisp and flavorful with a dry finish.

name: Kellerbier or Zwickelbier Ale
color: Varies depending on the underlying German ale style
clarity: Can be clear to moderately cloudy. Slight yeast haze is acceptable and traditional. These beers are unfiltered, but may become clear with age. May exhibit poor head retention.
perceived_malt: Kellerbier ales are unfiltered German-style Altbier or Koelsch. Malt aromas and flavors typical of these styles should be present.
perceived_hop: Varies depending on underlying style. Hop character may be muted by the presence of yeast.
perceived_bitterness: Varies depending on underlying style. Bitterness may be suppressed by the presence of yeast.
fermentation: Low to medium yeast aroma and flavor is desirable. Very low to moderately low levels of sulfur should be apparent. Low levels of acetaldehyde or other volatiles, normally reduced during lagering, may or may not be apparent. The presence of sulfur and acetaldehyde should enhance the flavor of these beers. Fruity-estery levels may vary slightly from the underlying styles due to age and presence of yeast.
notes: These unfiltered beers are packaged and served with low to moderate amounts of yeast. They may be filtered and dosed with yeast during packaging. Beers containing non-standard ingredients or aged in flavor-imparting vessels should be categorized elsewhere.

name: Berliner-Style Weisse
color: Straw to pale. These are the lightest of all the German wheat beers. Versions made with fruits or other flavorings may take on corresponding hues.
clarity: May appear hazy or cloudy from yeast or chill haze
perceived_malt: Malt sweetness is absent
fermentation: Fruity-estery aroma and flavor should be evident at low to medium levels. Diacetyl should not be perceived.
notes: Carbonation is high. Berliners are sometimes served with sweet fruit or herbal syrups. Contemporary examples may be brewed or served with fruit, spices or other ingredients.

name: Leipzig-Style Gose
clarity: Cloudy to bright. Haze may or may not be from yeast.
perceived_malt: Malt sweetness is not perceived to very low
fermentation: Medium to high lactic acid character should be evident and expressed as a sharp, refreshing sourness. These beers are not excessively aged.
notes: These beers typically contain malted barley and unmalted wheat, with some versions also containing oats. Salt (table salt) and coriander may be present in low amounts, or may be absent.

name: Contemporary-Style Gose
color: Usually straw to medium amber, and can take on the color of added fruits or other ingredients such as darker malts.
clarity: Cloudy/hazy with suspended yeast
perceived_malt: Malt aroma and flavor is not perceived to very low
fermentation: Horsey, leathery or earthy aromas contributed by
notes: These beers may be brewed with malted barley, wheat and oats and unmalted barley, wheat, and oats. contemporary examples may also contain other grains. As in traditional examples, low level salt (table salt) and coriander additions may or may not be present in Contemporary Gose. Attributes from the use of a wide variety of herbs, spices, floral or fruits not found in traditional Leipzig-Style Gose may also be present and in harmony with overall flavor profile.

name: South German-Style Hefeweizen
clarity: If served with yeast, appearance may be very cloudy.
perceived_malt: Very low to medium-low
fermentation: Med-low to med-high fruity and phenolic attributes are hallmarks of this style. Phenolic attributes such as clove, nutmeg, smoke and vanilla are present. Banana ester aroma and flavor should be present at low to medium-high levels. No diacetyl should be perceived.
notes: These beers are made with at least 50 percent malted wheat. Hefeweizens are very highly carbonated. These beers are typically (though not always) roused during pouring, and when yeast is present, they will have a yeasty flavor and a characteristically fuller mouthfeel.

name: South German-Style Kristal Weizen
clarity: Clear with no chill haze present. Because the beer is filtered, no yeast should be present.
perceived_malt: Malt sweetness is very low to medium-low
fermentation: The aroma and flavor is very similar to Hefeweizen with the caveat that fruity and phenolic characters are not combined with the yeasty flavor and fuller-bodied mouthfeel of yeast. The phenolic characteristics are often described as clove-like or nutmeg-like and can be smoky or even vanilla-like. A Banana-like ester aroma and flavor is often present. No diacetyl should be perceived. Kristal Weizens are well attenuated and very highly carbonated.
notes: These beers are made with at least 50 percent malted wheat. They have no yeast flavor and they exhibit a cleaner, drier mouthfeel than counterparts served with yeast.

name: German-Style Leichtes Weizen
clarity: If served with yeast, appearance may be very cloudy.
perceived_malt: Very low to medium-low
fermentation: The phenolic and estery aromas typical of Weissbiers should be present but less pronounced in this style. The overall flavor profile is less complex than Hefeweizen due to a lower alcohol content and there is less yeasty flavor. No diacetyl should be perceived.
body: Low with a lighter mouthfeel than Hefeweizen. The German word 'leicht' means light, and as such these beers are light versions of Hefeweizen.
notes: These beers are made with at least 50 percent wheat malt. They are often roused during pouring, and when yeast is present, they will have a yeasty flavor and a fuller mouthfeel.

name: South German-Style Bernsteinfarbenes Weizen
color: Amber to light brown. The German word
clarity: If served with yeast, appearance may be very cloudy.
perceived_malt: Distinct sweet maltiness and caramel or bready character is derived from the use of medium-colored malts
fermentation: The phenolic and estery aromas and flavors typical of Weissbiers are present but less pronounced in Bernsteinfarbenes Weissbiers. These beers should be well attenuated and very highly carbonated. No diacetyl should be perceived.
notes: These beers are made with at least 50 percent wheat malt. They are often roused during pouring, and when yeast is present, they will have a yeasty flavor and a fuller mouthfeel.

name: South German-Style Dunkel Weizen
clarity: If served with yeast, appearance may be very cloudy
perceived_malt: Distinct sweet maltiness and a chocolate-like character from roasted malt characterize this beer style. Dark barley malts are frequently used along with dark Cara or color malts.
fermentation: The phenolic and estery aromas and flavors typical of Weissbiers are present but less pronounced in Dunkel Weissbiers. Dunkel Weissbiers should be well attenuated and very highly carbonated. No diacetyl should be perceived
notes: These beers are made with at least 50 percent wheat malt. They are often roused during pouring, and when yeast is present, they will have a yeasty flavor and a characteristically fuller mouthfeel.

name: South German-Style Weizenbock
clarity: If served with yeast, appearance may be very cloudy.
perceived_malt: Medium malty sweetness should be present. If dark, a mild roast malt character should emerge in the flavor and, to a lesser degree, in the aroma.
fermentation: Balanced, clove-like phenolic and fruity-estery banana notes produce a well-rounded flavor and aroma. No diacetyl should be perceived. Carbonation should be high.
notes: These beers are made with at least 50 percent wheat malt. They are often roused during pouring, and when yeast is present, they will have a yeasty flavor and a fuller mouthfeel.

name: German-Style Rye Ale
color: Pale to very dark, with darker versions ranging from dark amber to dark brown.
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable in versions packaged and served without yeast. In versions served with yeast, appearance may range from hazy to very cloudy.
perceived_malt: In darker versions, malt aromas and flavors can optionally include low roasted malt characters expressed as cocoa/chocolate or caramel, and/or aromatic toffee, caramel, or biscuit attributes. Malt sweetness can vary from low to medium. Low level roast malt astringency is acceptable when balanced with low to medium malt sweetness.
fermentation: Low to medium banana-like and/or other fruity-estery aromas and flavors are typical. Clove-like and/or other phenolic aromas and flavors should also be present. No yeast aroma should be evident in versions without yeast. Versions packaged and served without yeast will not have yeast flavor or full mouthfeel typical of beers with yeast. Versions with yeast will have low to medium yeast aroma and flavor and a full mouthfeel, but the yeast character should not overpower the balance of rye and barley malts, esters and phenolics.
notes: Grist should include at least 30 percent rye malt. Versions with yeast are often roused during pouring. When yeast is present, the beer should have a yeasty flavor and a fuller mouthfeel.

name: Bamberg-Style Weiss Rauchbier
clarity: If served with yeast, appearance may be very cloudy.
perceived_malt: In darker versions, a detectable degree of roast malt may be present without being aggressive. Smoky malt aroma and flavor, ranging from low to high, should be present. Smoke character should be smooth, not harshly phenolic, suggesting a mild sweetness.
fermentation: The aroma and flavor of a Weiss Rauchbier with yeast should be fruity and phenolic. The phenolic characteristics are often described as clove, nutmeg, vanilla and smoke. Banana esters are often present at low to medium-high levels. No diacetyl should be perceived. Weissbiers are well attenuated and very highly carbonated.
notes: These beers are made with at least 50 percent wheat malt. They are often roused during pouring, and when yeast is present, they will have a yeasty flavor and a fuller mouthfeel.

name: Belgian-Style Blonde Ale
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Malt aroma and flavor is low
perceived_hop: Not perceived to low. Noble-type hops are commonly used.
fermentation: Low to medium fruity-estery aromas balanced with light malty and spicy aromas may be present. Low yeast-derived phenolic spiciness may be perceived. Diacetyl and acidic character should not be perceived.
notes: Theses beers should display a balance of light sweetness, spiciness and low to medium fruity-estery flavors.

name: Belgian-Style Pale Ale
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Malt aroma should be low. Caramel or toasted malt flavor is acceptable.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is low but noticeable. Noble-type hops are commonly used.
fermentation: Low to medium fruity-estery aromas and flavors are evident. Low levels of yeast-derived phenolic spicy flavors and aromas may be perceived. Diacetyl should not be perceived.

name: Belgian-Style Pale Strong Ale
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Malt character is low to medium. A complex fruitiness is often present.
fermentation: Low to medium fruity-estery aromas should be evident. Low levels of yeast-derived phenolic spicy flavors and aromas may also be perceived. Diacetyl, if present, should be at very low levels.
notes: These beers are often brewed with light-colored Belgian candy sugar. Herbs and spices are sometimes used to delicately flavor these strong ales. These beers can be malty in overall impression or dry and highly attenuated. They can have a deceptively high alcohol character and a relatively light body for beers of high alcoholic strength. Some versions may be equally high in alcohol with a more medium in body.

name: Belgian-Style Dark Strong Ale
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Medium to high malt aroma and complex fruity aromas are distinctive. Medium to high malt intensity can be rich, creamy and sweet. Fruity complexity along with soft roasted malt flavor adds distinct character.
fermentation: Very little or no diacetyl character should be perceived. Low levels of phenolic spiciness may be perceived.
notes: These beers are often (though not always) brewed with dark Belgian candy sugar. Herbs and spices are sometimes used to delicately flavor these strong ales. These beers can be well attenuated with a deceptive alcoholic strength.

name: Belgian-Style Dubbel
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Slight yeast haze may be evident in bottle conditioned versions.
perceived_malt: Cocoa, dark or dried fruit and/or caramel aroma attributes should be present along with malty sweetness.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aromas and flavors (especially banana) are appropriate at low levels. Diacetyl character should not be perceived.
notes: Head should be dense and mousse-like

name: Belgian-Style Tripel
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Traditional Tripels are bottle conditioned and may exhibit slight yeast haze. However, yeast should not be intentionally roused.
perceived_malt: Low sweetness from very pale malts should be present. There should be no roasted or dark malt character.
fermentation: A complex, sometimes mildly spicy, aroma and flavor characterize this style. Clove-like phenolic aroma and flavor may be very low. Fruity-estery aromas and flavors, including banana, are also common, but not required. Traditional Tripels are often well attenuated. Alcohol strength and flavor should be perceived.
notes: Head should be dense and mousse-like. Brewing sugar may be used to lighten the body. Hop/malt character should be balanced. The overall beer flavor may finish sweet, though any sweet finish should be light. Oxidized character, if evident in aged Tripels, should be mild and pleasant.

name: Belgian-Style Quadrupel
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Caramel, dark sugar and malty sweet flavors and aromas can be intense, but not cloying, and should complement fruitiness.
fermentation: Perception of alcohol can be strong. Complex fruity flavors, such as raisins, dates, figs, grapes and/or plums are often present and may be accompanied by wine-like attributes at low levels. Clove-like phenolic flavor and aroma should not be evident. Diacetyl and DMS should not be perceived.
notes: Head should be dense and mousse-like. Quadrupels are well attenuated and are characterized by an intense alcohol presence balanced by other flavors, aromas and bitterness. They are well balanced with savoring/sipping-type drinkability. Oxidized character, if present in aged Quads, should be mild and pleasant.

name: Belgian-Style Witbier
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
clarity: Unfiltered starch and yeast haze should be visible. Wits are traditionally bottle conditioned and served cloudy.
perceived_malt: Very low to low
fermentation: Low to medium fruity-estery aromas and flavors should be present. Diacetyl should not be perceived. Mild phenolic spiciness and yeast flavors may be evident. Mild acidity is appropriate.
body: Low to medium, with a degree of creaminess from wheat starch.
notes: Wits are brewed with malted barley, unmalted wheat and sometimes oats. They are spiced with coriander and orange peel. Coriander and light orange peel aroma may be perceived, sometimes as an unidentified spiciness.

name: Classic French & Belgian-Style Saison
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
clarity: Chill haze or slight yeast haze is acceptable
perceived_malt: Low, but providing foundation for the overall balance.
perceived_hop: Low to medium and characterized by European-type hops: floral, herbal and/or woody traits are common.
perceived_bitterness: Medium-low to medium, but not assertive.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aromas and flavors are medium to high. Diacetyl should not be perceived. Very low levels of

name: Specialty Saison
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
clarity: Chill haze or slight yeast haze is acceptable
perceived_malt: Typically low to medium-low, but may vary in beers made with specialty malts.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aromas are medium to high. Diacetyl character should not be perceived. Complex alcohols, herbs, spices, low
notes: Contemporary Specialty Saison represent a very wide family of specialty beers. Ingredients including spices, herbs, flowers, fruits, vegetables, fermentable sugars and carbohydrates, special yeasts of all types, wood aging, etc. may contribute unique attributes to these beers. Earthy and/or cellar-like aromas are acceptable. Color, body, malt character, esters, alcohol level and hop character should harmonize with attributes from special ingredients.

name: French-Style Bire de Garde
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable. These beers are often bottle conditioned so slight yeast haze is acceptable.
perceived_malt: These beers are characterized by a toasted malt aroma along with a slight malt sweetness and/or toasted malt flavor.
perceived_hop: Low to medium from noble-type hops
fermentation: Fruity-estery aromas are medium to high. Fruity-estery flavors can be light to medium. Diacetyl should not be perceived. Bire de Garde may have
notes: Earthy and/or cellar-like aromas are acceptable.

name: Belgian-Style Flanders Oud Bruin or Oud Red Ale
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
color: Copper to very dark. SRM/EBC color values can be misleading because the red spectrum of color is not accurately assessed by these measurement systems.
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures. Some versions may be more highly carbonated. Bottle conditioned versions may appear cloudy when served.
perceived_malt: Roasted malt aromas and flavors including cocoa are acceptable at low levels. A very low level of malt sweetness may be present and balanced by acidity from
perceived_bitterness: Very low to medium-low, though acidity and wood aging (if used) may mask higher bitterness levels.
body: Low to medium-low with a refreshing mouthfeel
notes: Oaky or woody flavors may be pleasantly integrated. Flavors of wine or distilled spirits associated with used barrels should not be evident. Bottle conditioned versions are often a blend of old and young beer to create the brewer's intended flavor balance.

name: Belgian-Style Lambic
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
clarity: Cloudiness is acceptable
perceived_malt: Sweet malt character should not be present
perceived_hop: Not perceived to very low, and can include cheesy or floral lavender character. Hop character is achieved by using stale and aged hops at low rates.
fermentation: Characteristic horsey, goaty, leathery and phenolic aromas and flavors derived from
notes:
Lambics originating in the Brussels area of Belgium are often simply called Lambic. Versions of this beer style made outside of the Brussels area cannot be called true Lambics. These versions are said to be 'Belgian-Style Lambic' and may be made to resemble many of the beers of true origin.
Historically, traditional Lambic is dry and completely attenuated, exhibiting no residual sweetness either from malt, sugar or other sweeteners. Sweet versions may be created through addition of sugars or other sweeteners. Traditionally, Lambics are brewed with unmalted wheat and malted barley.

name: Belgian-Style Gueuze Lambic
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
clarity: Cloudiness is acceptable, as Gueuze is nearly always bottle conditioned.
perceived_malt: Sweet malt character is not perceived
perceived_hop: Not perceived to very low, and can include a cheesy or floral or lavender-like attributes.
fermentation: Gueuze is characterized by intense fruity-estery, sour, and acidic aromas and flavors. Diacetyl character should be absent. Characteristic horsey, goaty, leathery and phenolic aromas and flavors derived from
notes: Gueuze Lambics, whose origin is the Brussels area of Belgium, are often simply called Gueuze Lambic. Versions of this beer style made outside of the Brussels area are said to be 'Belgian-Style Gueuze Lambics.' The Belgian-style versions are made to resemble many of the beers of true origin. Historically, traditional Gueuze Lambics are dry and completely attenuated, exhibiting no residual sweetness either from malt, sugar or other sweeteners. Traditionally, Gueuze is brewed with unmalted wheat, malted barley, and stale, aged hops. Some modern versions may have a degree of sweetness contributed by sugars or other sweeteners. See also Belgian-Style Lambic for additional background information.

name: Belgian-Style Fruit Lambic
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
color: Often influenced by the color of added fruit
clarity: Cloudiness is acceptable
perceived_malt: Malt sweetness should be absent, but sweetness of fruit may be low to high.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is not perceived. Cheesy hop character should not be perceived.
fermentation: Characteristic horsey, goaty, leathery and phenolic aromas and flavors derived from
notes: These beers, also known by the names Framboise, Kriek, Peche, Cassis, etc., are characterized by fruit aromas and flavors. Fruit Lambics, whose origin is the Brussels area of Belgium, are often simply called Fruit Lambic. Versions of this beer style made outside of the Brussels area are said to be 'Belgian-Style Fruit Lambics.' The Belgian-style versions are made to resemble many of the beers of true origin. Historically, traditional Lambics are dry and completely attenuated, exhibiting no residual sweetness either from malt, sugar, fruit or other sweeteners. Some versions often have a degree of sweetness contributed by fruit sugars, other sugars or other sweeteners. See also Belgian-Style Lambic for additional background information. Such beers exhibiting wood-derived attributes should be categorized in other Wood-Aged categories.

name: Other Belgian-Style Ale
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
clarity: Varies with style
perceived_malt: Malt perception, both in flavor and aroma, varies widely depending on style.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and hop flavor varies widely depending on style
fermentation: Varies with style
notes: Beers in this category recognize the uniqueness and traditions of Belgian brewing, but do not adhere to other Belgian-style categories defined in these guidelines. Balance is a key component when assessing these beers. Wood- and barrel-aged versions should be categorized as wood- and barrel-aged beers. Fruited versions should be categorized as Belgian-style fruit beers.

name: Belgian-Style Table Beer
style-origin: Belgian and French Origin Ale Styles
color: Gold to black. Caramel color is sometimes added to adjust color.
clarity: Beer color may be too dark to perceive. When clarity is perceivable, chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures.
perceived_malt: Mild malt character might be evident
fermentation: Diacetyl character should not be perceived. Traditional versions do not use artificial sweeteners nor are they excessively sweet. More modern versions can incorporate sweeteners such as sugar and saccharine added post fermentation for additional sweetness and to increase smoothness.
notes: These beers may contain malted barley, wheat, and rye as well as unmalted wheat, rye, oats and corn. Though not common, flavorings such as coriander or orange and lemon peel are sometimes added, but are barely perceptible. The mouthfeel is light to moderate, and sometimes boosted with unfermented sugars/malt sugars. Low carbonation and aftertaste are typical.

name: Grodziskie
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Oak-smoked wheat malt comprises the entire grain bill. Assertive smoked wheat malt aromas and flavors are medium to medium-high with aroma dominated by oak smoke.
perceived_hop: Aroma and flavor of noble hops ranges from not perceived to low
fermentation: Fruity-estery aroma and flavor should be low. Diacetyl and DMS should not be perceived. An overall crisp flavor is achieved by managing fermentation temperatures. Sourness should not be perceived.
notes: Grodziskie (also known as Graetzer) is an ale style of Polish origin. Historic versions were often bottle conditioned and highly carbonated.

name: Adambier
clarity: Beer color may be too dark to perceive. When clarity is perceivable, chill haze is absent.
perceived_malt: Toast and caramel malt aroma and flavor may be evident. Astringency from highly roasted malt should not be present.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is low. Traditional and non-hybrid varieties of European hops are traditionally used.
fermentation: A cool ale fermentation is typically used. Extensive aging and acidification of this beer can mask malt and hop character to varying degrees. Aging in barrels may contribute some level of
notes: The style originated in Dortmund and is a strong, dark, hoppy ale which may or may not be sour. It may also be extensively aged in wooden barrels. Traditional versions may have a low or medium-low degree of smokiness. Adambier may or may not use wheat in its formulation. Smoke character may be absent in contemporary versions. Fruited versions of this style which exhibit attributes of wood-aging should be categorized as fruited Wood- and Barrel-Aged Sour Beers. Fruited versions of this style which do not exhibit attributes of wood-aging should be categorized as Fruit Wheat Beers.

name: Dutch-Style Kuit, Kuyt or Koyt
clarity: Chill haze and other haze is acceptable
perceived_malt: The aroma is grainy or grainy-bready. The distinctive character of this beer is derived from the use of at least 45 percent oat malt, at least 20 percent wheat malt with pale malt making up the remainder of the grain bill.
perceived_hop: Very low to low from noble hops or other traditional European varieties
fermentation: Esters may be present at low levels. Very low levels of diacetyl are acceptable. Acidity and sweet corn-like DMS should not be perceived.
notes: This style of beer was popular in the Netherlands from 1400-1550

name: Classic Australian-Style Pale Ale
clarity: Chill haze and/or a hazy appearance caused by yeast is acceptable at low levels
perceived_malt: Low malt sweetness and other malt attributes are present
fermentation: Perceivable fruity-estery aroma and flavor should be present, and are defining character of this beer style, balanced by low to medium hop aroma. Overall flavor impression is mild. Clean yeasty, bready character may be evident. Yeast in suspension if present may impact overall perception of bitterness. Diacetyl if present should be very low. DMS should not be present.
body: Low to medium with a dry finish

name: Australian-Style Pale Ale
clarity: Yeast, chill and/or hop haze may be present in this style at low levels but are not essential
perceived_malt: Very low to medium
perceived_hop: Medium-low to medium-high, exhibiting attributes typical of modern Australian hop varieties such as tropical fruit, mango, passionfruit, and/or stone-fruit
fermentation: Very low to low fruity estery flavor and aroma are acceptable but not essential.
body: Low to low-medium with a dry finish
notes: Overall impression is a well-integrated easy drinking, refreshing pale ale style with distinctive fruity Australian hop aromas and flavours. Diacetyl if present should be very low. DMS should not be present.

name: International-Style Pale Ale
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Very low to medium malt flavor and aroma should be present. Low caramel malt aroma and flavor may be present.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma is low to high. Hop flavor is very low to high. Hop character can vary widely depending on variety and origin of hops used, and should reflect attributes typical of non-U.S. and non-British variety hops.
fermentation: Fruity-estery flavor and aroma can be low to high. Diacetyl should be absent or present at very low levels. DMS should not be present.

name: Finnish-Style Sahti
clarity: Chill haze, yeast haze and general turbidity is acceptable.
perceived_malt: Malt aroma is medium-low to medium. Malt flavor is medium to high with malt sweetness evident.
fermentation: These beers can vary significantly in character. Fruity-estery and yeasty aromas are medium to high. Diacetyl should not be perceived. Bread/bakers' yeast is traditionally used for fermentation and may produce flavors and aromas of complex alcohols, clove-like phenols and banana fruitiness.
notes: Juniper aroma and flavor should be evident due to the use of juniper boughs/branches and berries in the brewing process

name: Swedish-Style Gotlandsdricke
clarity: Chill haze or yeast haze is acceptable
perceived_malt: Malt aroma and flavor is medium-low to medium. Birchwood smoke character, derived from the malting process, should be present.
fermentation: Bread/bakers' yeast is traditionally used for fermentation and contributes to unique character of these beers. Fruity-estery and yeasty aromas are medium to high. Diacetyl should not be perceived.
notes: Juniper aroma and flavor should be evident due to the use of juniper boughs/branches and berries in the brewing process. These beers are characterized by juniper and birchwood smoked malt.

name: Breslau-Style Pale Schoeps
clarity: Chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures
perceived_malt: Malt sweetness is medium to medium-high. A high proportion of pale wheat malt (as much as 80 percent) is used to brew these beers as well as Pilsener and other pale specialty malts. They may have a bready, aromatic biscuit malt aroma, but should not display caramel character.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aromas may be evident as these beers are fermented with ale yeast as opposed to wheat beer yeast. Fruity-estery flavors may be present. Diacetyl and phenolic aromas and flavors should not be perceived.
notes: Traditional German wheat beer yeast is not used in this style of beer

name: Breslau-Style Dark Schoeps
clarity: Beer color may be too dark to perceive. When clarity is perceivable, chill haze is acceptable at low temperatures.
perceived_malt:
Malt sweetness is medium to medium-high. Roast malt bitterness may be evident at low levels.
A high proportion of dark wheat malt (as much as 80%) is used to brew these beers as along with other specialty toasted and dark specialty malts. They have a pronounced malt character with aromas of toasted or nutty malt, but lack caramel character.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aromas and flavors may be evident as these beers are fermented with ale yeast, but not with traditional wheat beer yeast. Diacetyl and phenolic aromas and flavors should not be perceived.

name: German-Style Pilsener
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: A malty sweet aroma and flavor should be present.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is moderate and pronounced, derived from late hopping (not dry hopping) with noble-type hops.
fermentation: Very low levels of DMS aroma and flavor, usually below most people's thresholds, may be detectable by trained or sensitive palates. Other fermentation or hop-derived sulfur aromas and flavors may be perceived at low levels. Fruity-estery aromas and flavors should not be perceived. These are well attenuated beers.
notes: The head should be dense, pure white and persistent.

name: Bohemian-Style Pilsener
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: A slightly sweet and toasted, biscuity, bready malt aroma and flavor is evident.
perceived_hop: Low to medium-low, derived from noble-type hops.
fermentation: Very low levels of diacetyl and DMS character, if perceived, are characteristic of this style and may accent malt character. Low levels of fermented malt-derived sulfur compounds may be evident.
notes: The head should be dense.

name: Munich-Style Helles
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Malt aroma and flavor are pronounced. Low levels of yeast-produced sulfur aromas and flavors may be present. Malt character is sometimes bready and suggestive of lightly toasted malted barley. There should be no caramel character.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma is not perceived to low. Hop flavor is very low to low, derived from noble-type hops.
perceived_bitterness: Low, derived from European noble-type hops.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aromas and flavors should not be perceived. Diacetyl should not be perceived. DMS should not be perceived. A very low level of fermentation-derived sulfur attributes may be evident in balance with other characters.

name: Dortmunder/European-Style Export
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Sweet malt character should be low and should not be caramelly
perceived_hop: Very low to low, derived from noble-type hops.
fermentation: Fruity-estery flavors and aromas should not be perceived. Diacetyl should not be perceived.

name: Vienna-Style Lager
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Characterized by malty aroma and light malt sweetness, which should have a lightly toasted malt character.
perceived_hop: Very low to low, derived from noble-type hops.
perceived_bitterness: Low to medium-low, clean and crisp.
fermentation: DMS, diacetyl, and fruity esters should not be perceived.

name: German-Style Maerzen
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Bready or biscuity malt aroma and flavor should be present. Sweet maltiness is medium-low to medium and leads to a muted clean hop bitterness. Malt flavors should be of light toast rather than strong caramel. Low level caramel character is acceptable.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is low and of noble character
fermentation: Fruity-estery and diacetyl aromas and flavors should not be perceived

name: German-Style Oktoberfest/Wiesn
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Sweet maltiness is low to medium-low
perceived_bitterness: Very low to low and in balance with the low sweet maltiness
fermentation: Fruity-estery and diacetyl aromas and flavors should not be perceived
notes: Today's Oktoberfest beers are similar to Dortmunder/European-Style Export beers

name: Munich-Style Dunkel
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Malt character is low to medium, with chocolate, roast, bread or biscuit aromas and flavors contributed by the use of dark Munich malt.
perceived_hop: Very low to low, derived from noble-type hops.
fermentation: Fruity-estery and diacetyl aromas and flavors should not be perceived
notes: Dunkels do not offer an overly sweet impression, but rather a balance between malt and dark malt sweetness and hop character.

name: European-Style Dark Lager
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Malt character is low to medium, with chocolate, roast, and malt aromas and flavors evident.
perceived_hop: Very low to low, derived from noble-type hops.
fermentation: Fruity-estery and diacetyl aromas and flavors should not be perceived.
notes: These beers offer a fine balance of sweet maltiness and hop bitterness.

name: German-Style Schwarzbier
color: Very dark brown to black, with a pale-colored head.
clarity: Beer color may be too dark to perceive. When clarity is perceivable, chill haze should not be present.
perceived_malt: Medium malt aroma displays a mild roasted malt character. Malt sweetness is low to medium, and displays a mild roasted malt character without bitterness.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is very low to low, derived from noble-type hops.
fermentation: Fruity-estery and diacetyl aromas and flavors should not be perceived

name: German-Style Leichtbier
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Low to medium
fermentation: Fruity-estery and diacetyl aromas and flavors should not be perceived. Very low levels of sulfur-related compounds are acceptable.

name: Bamberg-Style Helles Rauchbier
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Malt character is prominent with malt aromas suggesting lightly toasted sweet malted barley. Smoke beechwood character ranges from very low to medium. Smoky aroma should be not harshly phenolic. Sulfur may be present at low levels. There should be no caramel character. Smoke flavor may create a perception of mild sweetness.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is very low to low, derived from noble-type hops.
fermentation: Fruity-estery and diacetyl aromas and flavors should not be perceived

name: Bamberg-Style Maerzen Rauchbier
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Sweet toasted malt aroma should be present. Medium-low to medium toasted malt sweetness should be present. Aroma and flavor of smoked beechwood ranges from very low to medium. Smoke flavors should be smooth, without harshness. Aroma should strike a balance between malt, hop and smoke.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is very low to low, derived from noble-type hops.
fermentation: Fruity-estery and diacetyl aroma and flavor should not be perceived

name: Bamberg-Style Bock Rauchbier
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Medium to medium-high malt aroma and flavor should be present with very low to medium-high beechwood smoke aromas and flavors. Smoke flavors should be smooth, without harshness. Smoke flavor may create a perception of mild sweetness.
perceived_bitterness: Medium, increasing proportionately with starting gravity.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aromas and flavors, if present, should be minimal. Diacetyl should not be perceived.

name: German-Style Heller Bock/Maibock
color: Pale to light amber. The German word 'helle' means light-colored, thus Heller Bock is a pale beer.
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Light toasty and/or bready aroma and flavor is often evident. Roast or heavy toast/caramel malt aromas and flavors should not be present.
perceived_hop: Low to medium-low, derived from noble-type hops.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aromas and flavors, if present, should be low. Diacetyl should not be perceived.

name: Traditional German-Style Bock
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Traditional Bocks are made with all malt, and have high malt character with aromas of toasted or nutty malt, but not caramel. Traditional bocks display high malt sweetness. The malt flavor profile should display a balance of sweetness and toasted or nutty malt, but not caramel.
perceived_bitterness: Medium, increasing proportionately with starting gravity.
fermentation: Fruity-estery aromas and flavors if present, should be minimal. Diacetyl should not be perceived.

name: German-Style Doppelbock
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Pronounced aromas and flavors of toasted malted barley. Some caramel and toffee character can contribute to complexity in a secondary role. Malty sweetness is pronounced but should not be cloying. There should be no astringency from roasted malts.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma is absent. Hop flavor is low.
fermentation: Alcoholic strength is high. Fruity-estery flavors and aromas are commonly perceived at low to moderate levels. Diacetyl should be absent.

name: German-Style Eisbock
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Sweet malt character is very high
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is absent
fermentation: Alcohol may be perceived in aroma. Fruity-estery aromas and flavors may be evident, but not overpowering. Diacetyl should be absent. Alcoholic strength is very high.
notes: This is a stronger version of Doppelbock. Traditionally, these beers were created by freezing a Doppelbock and removing the ice, thus concentrating the alcohol.

name: Kellerbier or Zwickelbier Lager
color: Varies depending on the underlying German lager style
clarity: Can be slightly hazy to moderately cloudy. A small amount of yeast haze is acceptable and traditional. These beers must be unfiltered, but may become clear with age. May exhibit poor head retention.
perceived_malt: Varies depending on the underlying German lager style
perceived_hop: Varies depending on underlying style. Dry hopped beers are acceptable.
fermentation: Low to medium levels of sulfur should be apparent. Low levels of acetaldehyde or other volatiles normally scrubbed during fermentation may or may not be apparent in flavor and aroma. Subtle or low fruity-estery aromas and flavors may be apparent. Diacetyl should be absent. Kellerbier Lagers have low to medium carbonation.
notes: Kellerbier Lagers are unfiltered lagered versions of German lager beer styles such as Munich-Style Helles, Dunkel, Dortmunder/Export, Bohemian Pilsener and German Pilsener. Sulfur and acetaldehyde should enhance the flavor of these beers. These unfiltered beers are packaged and served with low to moderate amounts of yeast. Contemporary versions may be filtered and dosed with yeast during packaging.

name: American-Style Lager
clarity: Chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Malt sweetness is very low to low
fermentation: Light fruity-estery aroma and flavor is acceptable. Diacetyl should be absent.
notes: Corn, rice, or other grain or sugar adjuncts are often used. American Lagers are very clean and crisp, and aggressively carbonated.

name: American-Style Light Lager
clarity: Chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Very low
fermentation: Low fruity-estery aromas and flavors are acceptable. Diacetyl should be absent. Corn, rice, or other grain or sugar adjuncts are often used. These beers are characterized by an extremely high degree of attenuation. Final gravity is often less than 1.000 (0  Plato).
notes: These beers are high in carbonation. Flavor attributes typical of beer are usually very low when present. Calories should not exceed 125 per 12-ounce serving. Low carb beers should have a maximum carbohydrate level of 3.0 gm per 12 oz. (356 ml).

name: American-Style Amber Light Lager
color: Pale to medium amber. The word 'Light' refers to light body and reduced calories rather than color.
clarity: Chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Malt sweetness is very low but evident
fermentation: Low fruity-estery aromas and flavors are acceptable. Diacetyl should be absent. Corn, rice, or other grain or sugar adjuncts may be used but all-malt formulations are also made.
notes: Calories should not exceed 125 per 12-ounce serving. These beers are high in carbonation.

name: American-Style Pilsener
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Medium-low to medium
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is medium to high, exhibiting attributes typical of noble-type hops
fermentation: DMS, fruity-estery and diacetyl aromas and flavors should be absent.
notes: Up to 25% corn and/or rice in the grist should be used. Beers in this category hew to American-style lagers typical of the pre-Prohibition era.

name: Contemporary American-Style Pilsener
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Medium-low to medium
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is medium to high. While traditional versions exhibit hop-derived attribute typical of noble-type hops, contemporary versions will exhibit hop and aroma attributes typical of a wide range of American hop varieties, including citrus, fruit-like or others.
fermentation: DMS, fruity-estery and diacetyl aromas and flavors should be absent.
notes: Up to 25% corn and/or rice in the grist should be used. Beers in this category diverge from American-style lagers typical of the pre-Prohibition era by virtue of a wide range of hop aroma and flavor attributes.

name: American-Style Ice Lager
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Low malt sweetness is present
fermentation: Fruity-estery and diacetyl aromas and flavors should not be perceived
notes: This style is slightly higher in alcohol than most other light-colored American-Style lagers. It has few or no adjuncts. Typically, these beers are chilled before filtration so that ice crystals (which may or may not be removed) are formed. This process can contribute to a higher alcohol content (up to 0.5% more).

name: American-Style Malt Liquor
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Some malt sweetness is perceived
fermentation: Fruity-estery and complex alcohol aromas and flavors are acceptable at low levels. Alcohol should not be solvent-like. Diacetyl should not be perceived.
notes: Beers of this style are varied in character. Some malt liquors are only slightly stronger than American lagers, while others approach bock strength.

name: American-Style Amber Lager
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Low to medium-low caramel or toasted malt aromas and flavors should be present
fermentation: Fruity-estery and diacetyl aromas and flavors should be absent

name: American-Style Maerzen/Oktoberfest
clarity: Chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Malt aroma and flavor should express a light toasted character. Bready or biscuity malt aroma and flavor is acceptable. A low level of caramel character is acceptable. Sweet maltiness should be present.
fermentation: Fruity-estery and diacetyl aromas and flavors should not be perceived
notes: The American version of this classic German beer is distinguished by a more pronounced hop character

name: American-Style Dark Lager
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Low malt aroma and flavor may include low levels of caramel
perceived_bitterness: Very low to low, and dissipates quickly.
fermentation: Carbonation is high. Fruity-estery, DMS and diacetyl aromas and flavors should not be perceived.

name: Baltic-Style Porter
clarity: Often opaque. When clarity is perceivable, chill haze should not be present.
perceived_malt: Malt sweetness is medium-low to medium-high. Distinctive malt aromas and flavors of caramelized sugars, dark sugars and licorice along with chocolate character of roasted malts are present. Roasted dark malts may contribute coffee character but there should be no bitter or astringent flavors. Debittered roast malts are best used for this style.
perceived_hop: Very low. Floral hop aroma can complement aromatics.
fermentation: Due to its alcoholic strength, there may be very low to low levels of complex alcohol aromas and flavors and/or higher levels of fruitiness suggestive of berries, grapes and plums, but not banana. Fruity-estery aromas and flavors from warm fermentation is not appropriate. Diacetyl and DMS should not be apparent.
notes: Baltic Porter is brewed with lager yeast and fermented and lagered cold producing a smooth beer

name: Australasian, Latin American or Tropical-Style Light Lager
clarity: Chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Malt sweetness is absent
fermentation: Sugar adjuncts are often used to lighten the body and flavor, sometimes contributing to very low to low fruity-estery aromas and flavors of apple/pear. Diacetyl should be absent.
notes: Sugar, corn, rice, and other cereal grains are used as adjuncts.

name: International-Style Pilsener
clarity: Appearance should be bright; chill haze should not be present
perceived_malt: Residual malt aroma and flavor may be perceived at low levels
fermentation: Very low levels of DMS aroma and flavor are acceptable. Fruity-estery and diacetyl aromas and flavors should not be perceived.
notes: These beers are often brewed with rice, corn, wheat, or other grains making up part of the mash. Sugar adjuncts may be added during the wort production process.

name: Session Beer
style-origin: All Origin Hybrid/Mixed Lagers or Ales
color: The color should mimic the classic style upon which the beer is based
clarity: Appearance may vary from brilliant to hazy to cloudy and should mimic the classic style upon which the beer is based
perceived_malt: Should mimic the classic style upon which the beer is based
perceived_hop: Should mimic the classic style upon which the beer is based
perceived_bitterness: Should mimic the classic style upon which the beer is based
fermentation: Varies with underlying style
notes: This category includes any style of beer made lower in strength than described in the classic style guidelines. These beers should exhibit lower alcohol content than the classic style. Drinkability is key to a successful session beer. Beers exceeding 5.0% abv (4% abw) are not categorized as Session Beers. Beers which fit in another classic or traditional category should not be categorized as Session Beers.

name: American-Style Cream Ale
style-origin: All Origin Hybrid/Mixed Lagers or Ales
clarity: Chill haze should be very low or not be present
perceived_malt: Medium-low to medium pale malt aroma may be present. Caramel malt aroma and flavor should be absent. The dominant flavor is of pale malt sweetness at medium-low to medium levels. Corn or other adjuncts may be perceived at low levels.
perceived_hop: Hop aroma and flavor is very low to low or may be absent
fermentation: Fruity-estery aroma and flavor may be perceived. Sulfur and/or DMS should be absent or extremely low. Diacetyl should not be perceived.
